title: 111_hr3665
content: The Act is titled the "Ryan White Grantee Medicaid Payment Equity Act of 2009" and it addresses Medicaid payment for services provided by Ryan White Part C grantees on a cost-based prospective payment system. The "Ryan White Grantee Medicaid Payment Equity Act of 2009" amends the Social Security Act to provide for Medicaid payment for services by Ryan White Part C grantees starting in fiscal year 2010. The "Ryan White Grantee Medicaid Payment Equity Act of 2009" amends the Social Security Act to provide Medicaid payment for services by Ryan White Part C grantees in fiscal year 2010, based on the costs of furnishing services in 2008 and 2009. The State plan shall provide payment for services in fiscal year 2011 and beyond based on the methodology used in the previous year, adjusted for any changes in services provided. Payment shall be calculated on a per visit basis and increased by the percentage increase in the MEI applicable to primary care services. The State plan shall provide payment for Medicaid covered services furnished by new grantees in the first fiscal year after 2009, based on the costs of furnishing such services during that year. The payment amount is calculated on a per visit basis and is equal to 100 percent of the costs, adjusted for any changes in services provided. The State plan provides payment for Medicaid covered services by new grantees based on costs in the first fiscal year after 2009. Payment is calculated per visit and adjusted for service changes. Grantees in managed care contracts receive supplemental payments as specified by the Secretary. The State plan allows for supplemental payments to new grantees for Medicaid covered services based on agreed-upon payment schedules. Alternative payment methodologies can also be used if agreed upon by the State and the grantee. The amendments made by subsection (a) apply to services furnished on or after January 1, 2010, without final regulations. State legislation may be required for a State plan to meet additional requirements for medical assistance under title XIX of the Social Security Act. The State plan must meet additional requirements imposed by the amendments without being considered non-compliant solely for not meeting the requirement before the first day of the first calendar quarter after the State legislature's session. Each year of a 2-year legislative session is considered a separate regular session.
